node.title: Question about the INSBase.c file
finite element method works in moose
node.bodyText:
Dear all, could you please help with the following questions：


how does the finite element method works in moose? for example, if we have a 1D domain with 5 global nodes, now we need to solve two different equations such as the mass equation and the Navier stokes equation. In the end, we will sum up all the residuals from two equations together such that residual from eq 1+residual from eq 2=0 ?


Similarly, if we have momentum equations in 3 directions, will we sum up all residuals from 3 directions and let it =0?


In the Navier stokes equation, we may have a double derivative of velocity in the viscous term, after we multiply the test function, we still have a gradient of velocity which is one variable I want to solve. whenever I use _grad_u to represent it, moose tells me some error. Is it because the grad_u (gradient of velocity) is a tensor since velocity is a tensor?


Thanks a lot.
J

Hello
No sum of residuals involved. The residuals are a field for each equation
Maybe this documentation page will help
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/systems/NonlinearSystem.html#newtons_method
_grad_u is of the type you specified in the header of the source file.
If u is the whole velocity vector, then yes it s a tensor.
If u is just a component, then grad_u can be a vector
Guillaume

Hello
No sum of residuals involved. The residuals are a field for each equation Maybe this documentation page will help https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/systems/NonlinearSystem.html#newtons_method
_grad_u is of the type you specified in the header of the source file. If u is the whole velocity vector, then yes it s a tensor. If u is just a component, then grad_u can be a vector
Gyukkayne

Thanks for your answers, Gyukkayne. I learned an INSADMaterial in navier_stokes module of MOOSE.
_INSADMaterial::INSADMaterial(const InputParameters & parameters)
  : Material(parameters),
    _velocity(adCoupledVectorValue("velocity")),
    _grad_velocity(adCoupledVectorGradient("velocity")),_

Here. the _velocity and _grad_velocity are all Vectors. It may not match the 'If u is the whole velocity vector, then yes it s a tensor.' Is it correct ? Thanks.
J

See the doxygen for that adCoupledVectorGradient
const ADVectorVariableGradient & | adCoupledVectorGradient (const std::string &var_name, unsigned int comp=0) const

Then clicking on the return type:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/MooseTypes_8h.html#ac94e300de96c5e84492712644437fcb9
It is a tensor.

See the doxygen for that adCoupledVectorGradient
const ADVectorVariableGradient & | adCoupledVectorGradient (const std::string &var_name, unsigned int comp=0) const

Then clicking on the return type: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/MooseTypes_8h.html#ac94e300de96c5e84492712644437fcb9 It is a tensor.

Good, Guillaume. Thank you.
Today I learn the navier_stokes. I find that there are two methods used to write the kernels for incompressible and compressible fluids in the navier_stokes module.


Using ADKernels. In the related ADkernels, the velocity is a vector and is not defined as 3 components.  The strong form residuals are defined as properties in the Materials and are directly used in the related ADKernels.


Using Kernels. In the related kernels, the velocity is a vector and defined as 3 components.  Each component is a scalar. The weak form residuals are written in the related Kernels.


I find that the incompressible fluid has the above two methods, but the compressible fluid only has the Kernel method. So I have questions about them.

InCompressible fluid

(1) Is there some difference between the two methods used for incompressible fluid besides their intrinsic differences (e.g., the ADkernel doesn't need the hand-coded Jacobian, etc)?
(2) How could I choose them? Is the ADkernels with strong form residuals better than the Kernels with weak form residuals?

Compressible fluid

Can the ADKernels method with strong form residual be used for compressible fluid? How could I choose between the strong form residual and weak form residual if I use ADkernel method?
Thanks for your help.
J

So whether a vector or 3 components are used is completely an implementation choice. We generally prefer using vectors for velocity, but it required more work.
Anything AD does not need to use a hand coded jacobian. That is the point of automatic differentiation, to be able to compute the derivatives of the residual to form the Jacobian.
ADKernels still use the weak form. What you are seeing creating the strong form residual is for the purpose of SUPG stabilization. The weak form is still used for most of the solve
I recommend using ADKernels and implenenting the weak form

We generally prefer using vectors for velocity, but it required more work.

Thanks, Guillaume.  I am using the ADKernels and implementing the weak form for my problem.
'We generally prefer using vectors for velocity, but it required more work.'  Sorry, I don't understand what 'more work' means here.
J
In MOOSE we started by developing regular field variables. Vector variables came later and needed more development to work.

Hello
I think _u is rho * v_x here.
This would be because the conserved variables (density, momentum, energy) are used for this set of kernels.
Guillaume

Hello
I think _u is rho * v_x here. This would be because the conserved variables (density, momentum, energy) are used for this set of kernels.
Guillaume

yes, I know this. but u_vel is also _u, why do they have different expression and how moose can recognise that both are the same variable?
u_vel is just the velocity not the momentum

node.title: Two Equation Turbulence Model
node.bodyText:
As mentioned elsewhere, the finite element module of MOOSE does not have a two-equation turbulence model. Now we are trying to add this module, but we have encountered many problems. I wonder whether any experts have tried to add a two-equation turbulence model, or which users have done such work based on MOOSE.
Thanks
@lindsayad

In fact, I think I saw an expert who developed the K-Epsilon turbulence model in 2017, but it seems to have broken down halfway through, and now I'm developing the K-Omega turbulence model, which is able to do some simple examples, and the results look good, but in a slightly more complicated problem, there are convergence problems, I wonder if there is an opportunity to exchange such questions with experts in this question.

There is an issue for this: #9007. From that issue you can link to some commits that I worked on a very long time ago. We (the MOOSE team) do not have programmatic funding to work on the finite element side of the navier_stokes module, but we would love any outside contribution that added that capability. I do not know whether my old commits would help you in any way, but please feel free to work from them if they are of any help. If you do decide to develop this yourself, I may be able to provide some limited coaching as my time allows

Hi, Prof. lindsayad
Thanks for your reply. I would like to describe some of the problems I encountered in the development of turbulence programs.
I had finished a kind of two turbulence model which is Wilcox k-omega turbulence model, and I had finished testing some important cases like the "2D Zero Pressure Gradient Flat Plate Verification Case" and “backward-facing-step Case". When I simulated the above simple cases, convergence is fine and from the computed solution I could find that the relationship between u+ and log(y+) compared with the DNS solution is about the same in the "2D Zero Pressure Gradient Flat Plate Verification Case". But in other complex cases, I always face a big issue which is a convergence problem. As I know, in other FVM programs we need to use some method to stabilize the simulation for turbulence equation in particular the production and dissipation term, but in FEM programs I wonder if there is a method to stabilize simulation like SUPG/PSPG.
Looking forward to your reply. Thanks.

In the navier_stokes module in our FEM implementation, we have both SUPG and PSPG available. However, if you want to add a turbulence model, you would have to implement the SUPG stabilization of the additional equations yourself, e.g. you would have to develop the SUPG stabilization of k and epsilon for a k-epsilon model. Additionally if you add an additional term like a Reynolds stress for the turbulent momentum transport, you would have to add that term into the existing SUPG and PSPG stabilization of the momentum and mass equations.
If you have not seen it already, we have an article on the FEM portion of the navier_stokes module. The journal article is here; if you do not have access, there is an arXiv version of it here.

Thank you for your reply in spite of your busy schedule. I am sorry that my description may not be accurate, so you did not understand what I mean.
Yes, I did add SUPG stabilization to the k and omega equation according to the journal article named "Overview of the Incompressible Navier Stokes simulation capabilities in the MOOSE Framework". But due to the production terms of those turbulence equations are too complex to add the jacobian term to matrix by hand. Then I tried to add those jacobian terms by AD, which will cause non-convergence. In other words, my Jacobian matrix is right made by hand, but it is the production term of those turbulence equations is complex that causes the convergence problem even though I had added SUPG to those equations. So I wonder if there are need to add other stabilization methods to those turbulence equations to stabilize those turbulence equations' simulation, or if there are some other details worth noting I did not know.

Then I tried to add those jacobian terms by AD, which will cause non-convergence.

I doubt that the AD-generated Jacobian caused non-convergence. You can check the accuracy of your Jacobian by running with the PETSc command-line option -snes_test_jacobian.
What Reynolds numbers are you trying to run at? Maybe @tanoret would have some comment on stability of the k-epsilon equations

Thanks for your reply,
Your advice is of great help to me. I had finished running with the PETSc command-line option '-snes_test_jacobian'. And I found that the Jacobian is not very accurate. However, that's not the root cause. I tried to run with the FDP(Finite Difference Preconditioner) which could build the perfect approximate Jacobian. But some otherwise solvable problems do not converge. So I doubt that the residual term of production and dissipation caused non-convergence. Maybe those terms need to be restricted, but I have never found references such as literature or code implementing restrictions by the finite element method.
Looking forward to your reply. Thanks.
I could help try to debug this, but you would need to submit a pull request for me to do so

Thanks again for your reply, and I really appreciate you would like to help me to debug this by taking time out of your busy schedule.
Now I have finished pushing those codes to Github, you could pull it through https://github.com/suqingji/i_flow.git.
I have added a readme.md file to /i_flow/case/backstep_sparse/, if you have any questions about i_flow, please contact me at suqj5@mail2.sysu.edu.cn or here.

node.title: My test ran a few steps and quit.
node.bodyText:
Thank you for your reply
Environment Name Not Found : Could not find  conda environment: moose
You can list all discoverable environments with
But when l run the command "mamba activate mouse". The above situation will occur.
@guidguid

Hello
You need to follow the instructions from the beginning. Likely the environment did not get created, or you skipped the 'close and reopen your console' part.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
Also please do not open new posts for the next reply.
Guillaume

node.title: Diffusion problem cannot converge with small scale model
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm trying to do a simple transient diffusion calculation within a small domain with size of 50*50 µm. It somehow cannot converge properly. The input file is here: https://github.com/Chaoyue-Liu/battery/blob/main/problem/simplediffusion.i
I also tried to calculate the same problem at steady state, by ignoring TimeDerivative kernel and adding a DirichletBC condition. The calculation works well (https://github.com/Chaoyue-Liu/battery/blob/main/problem/steady_diffuison.i), but if I calculate this in transient, it doesn't converge https://github.com/Chaoyue-Liu/battery/blob/main/problem/Transient_diffusion.i . Could you check what am I doing wrong? Thank you!

Hello
The residuals are very small on this case, because you are very close to the solution with your 0 initialization it seems.
You can raise the tolerances on the linear and nonlinear solver when the solver seems to never accept the solution, even though the residual is very small.
This input converges fine

    [Mesh]
        type = GeneratedMesh
        dim = 2
        nx = 50
        ny = 50
        xmax = 0.00005
        ymax = 0.00005
    []
    
    [Variables]
    [phis]
    []
    []
    
    [Materials]
    [d]
    type=GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names='sigmas'
    prop_values='1'
    []
    []
    
    [Kernels]
    [ohm_s]
    type=MatDiffusion
    variable=phis
    diffusivity='sigmas'
    []
    [time_s]
    type=TimeDerivative
    variable=phis
    []
    []
    
    [ICs]
    [phis_ic]
    type=ConstantIC
    variable=phis
    value=0
    []
    []
    
    [BCs]
    [phis_neumann]
    boundary='bottom'
    type=ADNeumannBC
    variable=phis
    value=0.0001
    []
    [phis_dirichlet]
    boundary='top'
    type=ADDirichletBC
    variable=phis
    value=0
    []
    []
    
    [Executioner]
    type=Transient
    dt=1
    end_time=100
    automatic_scaling=true
    nl_abs_tol = 1e-12
    l_tol = 1e-8
    []
    
    [Outputs]
    exodus=true
    []

PS: the links are not set up properly, you need to do this : [text for the link](address for the link)
Thank you. It is indeed the problem with tolerance. I increased it and it converges fine. Thanks for the guidance.

node.title: moose installation
node.bodyText:
Hai,
while installing moose through ssh, after entering this command
[conda create --name moose moose-libmesh moose-tools]
screen showing like this below
Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source.
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): - failed
so i cant able to activate moose (conda activate moose). kindly help me with this. Thanking You

Hello
It could be that you have the old channel for idaholab
can you please try to remove it conda config --remove  <channel address>
then follow these instructions again from adding the channel onwards.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
Guillaume

node.title: My test ran a few steps and quit.
node.bodyText:
Hello,everyone!
My test ran a few steps and quit.
The following is the report information：
=   BAD TERMINATION OF ONE OF YOUR APPLICATION PROCESSES
=   PID 33867 RUNNING AT cu03
=   EXIT CODE: 9
=   CLEANING UP REMAINING PROCESSES
=   YOU CAN IGNORE THE BELOW CLEANUP MESSAGES
===================================================================================
YOUR APPLICATION TERMINATED WITH THE EXIT STRING: Killed (signal 9)
This typically refers to a problem with your application.
Please see the FAQ page for debugging suggestions

Can you help me?
Chen Rui

Hello
this isn’t enough information to see what went wrong.
could you please use a debugger to get us a backtrace? See this page for instructions
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html
guillaume
Also could you please describe the test a little bit. What does it? Any parallelism? Is it all moose objects or is there custom ones from your app?
@KangChenRui any update on this?

Hi, GiudGiud
I am trying to debug with debugger.
Thanks for your reply!

Hi, GiudGiud
The following is the background output information corresponding to the inputfile.
Can you help me?
Thanks for your reply!
nohup.out.txt

signal 9 (at the end of the log) is sigkill.
Did you kill the process?
Or are you running out of time on a cluster session?
Another possiblity is that you are running out of memory. Can you try to reduce the problem and see if it runs?
Also there is a postprocessor to keep track of memory usage:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/MemoryUsage.html
The log seems fine except for this sigkill

EnvironmentNameNotFound: Could not find conda environment: moose
You can list all discoverable environments with conda info --envs.
That's it
Look forward to your reply, thank you！

You should re-install the environment.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html

node.title: Transfering between subdomains
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Please I am trying to use domain decomposition features for a simple BVP equation with two subdomains.
I have issues transferring calculated variable from one domain to the other other domain.
It is telling me my auxvariable in the second domain is defined, which is clearly not.

My error, parent input file and sub input file are attached.
---------Main input file ----------------
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 1
  xmax = 1
[]

[Variables]
  [u]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [flux_var_u]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diff]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = u
    diffusivity = 2
  []
  [reaction]
    type = Reaction
    variable = u
    rate = 0.5
  []
  [bodyforce]
    type = BodyForce
    variable = u
    value = 1.
  []
  [td]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = u
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [fluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = 2
    variable = flux_var_u
    diffusion_variable = u
    component = x
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [left]
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = u
    boundary = left
    value = -3
  []
  [right]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = u
    boundary = right
    value = 0
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [average]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = u
  []
[]

[Executioner]

  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-12
  
  #end_time = 2
  #dt = 0.2

  picard_max_its = 10

  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  picard_rel_tol = 1e-6
  picard_abs_tol = 1e-10

  num_steps = 5
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

[MultiApps]
  [micro]
    type = TransientMultiApp
    positions = '0.5 0 0'
    input_files = 'sub_input.i'
    execute_on = timestep_end
    output_in_position = true
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [push_u]
    type = MultiAppPostprocessorToAuxScalarTransfer
    to_multi_app = micro
    from_postprocessor = average
    to_aux_scalar = flux_var_v
  []

  [pull_v]
    type = MultiAppPostprocessorInterpolationTransfer
    from_multi_app = micro
    variable = flux_var_u
    postprocessor = vt
  []
[]



----------Sub input file---------------
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 1
  xmax = 1
[]

[Variables]
  [v]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [flux_var_v]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diff]
    type = Diffusion
    variable = v
    #diffusivity = 2
  []

  [reaction]
    type = Reaction
    variable = v
    rate = 0.5
  []

  [body_force]
    type = BodyForce
    variable = v
    value = 1
  []

  [td]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = v
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [fluxKernel]
    type = DiffusionFluxAux
    diffusivity = 2
    variable = flux_var_v
    diffusion_variable = v
    component = x
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [left]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = v
    boundary = left
    value = 0
  []
  [right]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = v
    boundary = right
    value = 0
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]  # calc a single scalar (real) value
  [vt]
    type = ScalarVariable
    variable = flux_var_v
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  end_time = 2
  dt = 0.2

  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10

  solve_type = 'PJFNK'

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

Thanks you!!

Hello
MultiAppPostprocessorToAuxScalarTransfer is the wrong transfer here.
You are transferring to a field auxiliary variables, not a scalar one.
The transfer for that is
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/transfers/MultiAppVariableValueSamplePostprocessorTransfer.html
Guillaume

Thank you for your response. I changed it to the Variable Value Sampler too
and I was still hooked somewhere.
I will have to use one of the examples as a starting point, and build from
there.

Thank you!
…
On Tue, 11 Oct 2022 at 16:15, Guillaume Giudicelli ***@***.***> wrote:
 Hello

 MultiAppPostprocessorToAuxScalarTransfer is the wrong transfer here.
 You are transferring to a field auxiliary variables, not a scalar one.
 The transfer for that is

 https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/transfers/MultiAppVariableValueSamplePostprocessorTransfer.html

 Guillaume

node.title: what kernel should be used for the bulk free energy part of Moelans (2011) paper
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
I am trying to apply the approach in Moelans(2011) paper Acta Material 59 (2011) 1077-1086 on multi-phase model.
Attached is the evolution of the non-conserved order parameter. The first part is used to describe surface free energy and the second circled part is used to describe bulk free energy

I have found kernel ACGrGrMulti can be used for surface free energy part, but I have not found any kernel for the bulk energy part.
Any idea for this?
Best
Yixi
@dschwen @laagesen

Hi Yixi, unfortunately we do not currently have any existing kernels for the boxed part of the equation. You would need to write some code to implement this. We would welcome a contribution if you do so!

node.title: VSCode setup
node.bodyText:
Was dismayed to see atom being sunsetted.  But thanks to Moose team for giving us an alternative.
I made it to the "Recommended settings" step of the instructions.  Where and how do I add this to VSCode?  For example, do I save it in a file with a special name? etc.  In VSCode, I can open the settings but there are thousands of things.  I have no idea where to put the provided code.
Thanks,
Joe Kelly

Hi Joe
Yeah in VSCode you need to press: shift cmd P to pull up the settings bar
Then Preferences: Open User Settings
and paste it there
Best,
Guillaume
I ll add it to the docs

IIRC there are Open User Settings (UI), Open User Settings (json), Open Workspace Settings (UI) and Open Workspace Settings (json).
User settings will be the global settings for all projects, while Workspace settings is specific to each project (it will actually save the settings in json format in the .vscode folder in the current workspace). Depending on your actual need, you may have to choose between user settings and workspace settings.
UI will open settings inside vscode with some nice user interface, and json is its reflection in json format. They should be interoperable.

I always have to refer to past instructions as well. I believe you're after editing your workbench settings for that portion. Straight from my own notes (this is for Macintosh machines. The short cut keys will be different for Linux users:
edit the setting.json using keys `cmd+,` (command + comma), search for `workbench color`,
Click `Edit in settings.json`, append the following...

... the following being what ever it was you are trying to add/or edit to workbench settings, in json format. It's a button at the top right (for me). See attached picture.

The key was finding the "edit JSON Button".
Thanks for the help everyone.
Joe
